entry.title: Enabling Joule Studio in SAP Build for existing Joule customers
entry.content:
Introduction

This post is intended for existing Joule customers who are looking to enable Joule Studio and start building custom Joule skills.

If you're enabling Joule for the first time—for example, with SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, or SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud—and want to activate Joule Studio alongside, we recommend starting with the Discovery Center mission: Establish a Unified Joule Instance. You should also check out the helpful blog series by my colleague @Diganta_Mandal, starting with Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.

On the other hand, if you’ve already enabled Joule with any of the SAP cloud solutions mentioned above and have an active Formation of type Integration with Joule (you can verify this in your BTP Global Account under System Landscape > Formations), then this blog will guide you through the steps to activate Joule Studio within your existing setup.


Motivation

We often receive questions from existing customers about how to enable Joule Studio. Some of the most common ones include:

  • Do we need to run the Joule booster again to enable Joule Studio in SAP Build?
  • Does SAP Build Process Automation need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance?

You’ll find answers to these and other key questions as you continue reading this blog post.

Prerequisites Before You Begin

  • Make sure your global account has the SAP Build entitlement, specifically the plan: build-default (Application).
  • Confirm that your SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant is included in your existing Formation.
  • Next, subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation with the plan: build-default (Application) in any subaccount of your choice. For guidance, refer to the Provisioning Setup section in Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio. Note: You can skip the Joule Booster step in this case.

Important: Joule Studio is not compatible with tenants using the SAP Build Process Automation (plan: standard). A new subscription using the build-default plan is required.

If your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant is not already part of your Formation and doesn't appear under System Landscape > Systems in your global account, you will need to manually add it.

Steps below for adding  SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in your system landscape.

  1. Navigate to System Landscape > Systems and switch to the Service Owner View.









  2. Click on Add System and enter the details of your Cloud Identity Services tenant.


Steps to add SAP Build Process Automation in existing formation

  1. Go to your existing Formation of type Integration with Joule.

  2. Click Include Systems to launch the system inclusion wizard.
    Note: Your formation may already include systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public/Private Cloud, or other supported solutions.

    Answer to Question 1 (from the Motivation section):
    If Joule is already running with other solutions, you do not need to run the Joule Booster again to enable Joule Studio.


  3. In this example, a new subaccount named Joule Studio was created specifically for this purpose, with SAP Build Process Automation (plan: build-default) enabled in it.

    Answer to Question 2 (from the Motivation section):
    SAP Build Process Automation does not need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance.

  4. Select the Joule Studio subaccount and click Next Step.



  5. Choose Enable Capability Deployment, then proceed with Next Step.

  6. Review the summary and click Include.



    Your formation will begin synchronizing.



After a short while, if all steps have been completed successfully, the formation status will change to Ready.

You’re now set to start using Joule Studio to build and deploy your own custom Joule skills.



To continue, follow the next steps in the blog to:

  • Assign roles for Joule Skills developers. Refer Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.
  • Begin skill development using this blog post: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 2: Developing and Deploying a Joule Skill

entry.title: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio
entry.content:
Build Maintenance Validation Skills Using Joule Studio  in SAP Build (Part 1)

Intro: Empowering Maintenance Operations with Joule Skills

Joule Studio enables business users and developers to build Joule Skills that automate backend tasks and simplify decision-making. In this hands-on guide — the first of a two-part series —We’ll walk through creating a set of Joule Skills that help retrieve maintenance orders, fetch material and component details, and check stock availability, forming the foundation for intelligent decision-making, using a CAP-based service on SAP BTP.

We’ll focus specifically on how to design, build, and test Joule Skills inside Joule Studio. The backend logic used to check maintenance order status and stock availability is already deployed as a reusable service on SAP BTP and exposed through a destination.  

Use Case: Intelligent Maintenance Stock Validation 

Maintenance planners often face delays when required components for maintenance orders are unavailable. The validation process today is manual and error prone. 

With Joule Studio, we can automate this. Our Joule Skills we’ll build will: 

  • Retrieve pending maintenance orders 
  • Identify components required 
  • Check material stock availability 
  • Return the result to the user or agent consuming the skill

 

Now that we've outlined the business challenge and solution approach, let's dive into the hands-on implementation. We'll build this step-by-step, starting with the foundational setup and progressing through skill creation.

Prerequisites

Before we begin building our maintenance validation skills, you'll need access to Joule Studio. If you don't have Joule Studio set up yet, please follow the comprehensive setup guide available at: How to Get Started with Joule Studio

This guide will walk you through:

  • Accessing Joule Studio in your SAP BTP environment
  • Setting up the necessary entitlements and subscriptions
  • Configuring your development environment
  • Understanding the basic Joule Studio interface

Our Development Approach:

  1. First, we'll establish the connection to our backend service.
  2. Then, we'll create individual skills for each business function.
  3. Finally, we'll test and deploy our skills for use.

Step 1: Configure the Destination in SAP Build Lobby 

To connect Joule Studio to the backend service, you’ll first configure a destination directly in the SAP Build Control Tower. 

This destination will point to an already deployed CAP service that exposes the necessary maintenance order and stock validation logic. 

Create a New Destination 

  1. Navigate to the SAP Build Lobby .
  2. Go to Control Tower > Destinations.
  3. Click “Open in BTP Cockpit”.
  4. In the BTP Cockpit, Navigate to:
    • Connectivity > Destinations

 

5. Click Create Destination and fill in the following configuration: 

  • Name: sample-maintenance-service 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Description: Maintenance Order Service
  • URL: https://sample-maintenance-srv-i760021.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/maintenance-order 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • Authentication: BasicAuthentication 
  • User: TECHNICAL_USER 
  • Password: TECHNICAL_PASS

 

 

 

6.  Click Check Connection to verify the destination. You should see a green checkmark if the connection is successful.

Step 2: Create an Environment in SAP Build 

Before adding destinations or creating skills in Joule Studio, you need to create an environment in SAP Build. This environment acts as the runtime space where your agents and skills will be deployed and executed. 

To create an environment: 

  1. Open the SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Environments 
  3. Click Create Environment 
  4. Enter a name for your environment, e.g., Joule studio demo 
  5. (Optional) Add a description if needed 
  6. Click Create 

Later, you’ll associate your destination and actions with this environment to make them usable in your skills and agents 

Step 3: Add the Destination to SAP Build  

Now that your destination is created in BTP, as we did in Step 1, we need to make it available inside SAP Build to use it in Joule Studio. 

  1. Open SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Destinations 
  3. Click Add 
  4. In the wizard: Select your destination (e.g. sample-maintenance-service) 
  5. Click Next 
  6. Associate an Environment 
    1. Select the environment you created in Step 2(e.g., Joule_studio_demo) 
    2. You can choose to make the destination available in all environments or only the specific environment which you created in step 2 .
  7. Click Add Destination 

Once added, this destination will now be available to associate with environments and to use in Joule skills. 

Step 4: Add an Action in SAP Build (Expose Your API) 

Now that your destination is available and associated with an environment, the next step is to create an Action that defines how your backend API should be called by Joule skills. 

Actions are the bridge between destinations (backend APIs) and Joule Skills. 

You can upload an open API specification or build an action from scratch using the destination you added. 

Option 1: Upload OpenAPI Spec from Your Project 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Upload API Specification 
  3. Note:The API spec is provided as a .txt file containing JSON content in the attachment.
    Before uploading, rename the file to have a .json extension  so Joule Studio correctly detects the format.
  4. Upload your openapi.json file. 
  5. Click Next to continue 
  6. You’ll now be prompted to Create an Action Project. 
  7. Fill in Project Name and Description according to your use case.
    • For example, you can name the project Maintenance Fulfillment Agent API , since these APIs will later be used by a Joule Agent (covered in Part 2 of this series). 
  8. After creating the action project, you will see a list of all endpoints from your uploaded specification (you can select maximum up to 20) 
    • Select all the 6 endpoints needed for your use case. 
    • Click Add to include them in the project. 

8. Once the action is created, go to the Test tab and select the destination you created. Since the maintenance order API lists all orders, no input is required by default. If you'd like to filter by status (e.g., pending, open), you can add that later as an input parameter. Click Test to verify that the API returns a valid response. 

 

9. You should see 200: OK response from the API. 

Once tested, you can release the project to create a version of it. 

 

 10.Once released, click Publish to make the version available for Joule Skill creation 

Note: Releasing and publishing the action is required. Unpublished actions won’t appear when building a Joule Skill. 

Option 2: Alternatively: Build the Action from Scratch 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Build from Scratch 
  3. Fill in the required fields: 
    • Operation: GET 
    • Name: Enter a name for your action (e.g., CheckMaintenanceStock) 
    • Description: Enter a brief description (e.g., Checks stock for components in a maintenance order) 
    • Endpoint: eg., /MaintenanceOrder) 
  4. Define any request parameters and expected response fields. 
  5. Click Release and Publish the action just like in the previous method for the actions to be available. 

For our use case, we will be using Option 1. 

Step 5: Create a Project and Joule Skills 

Now that the destination is configured, the environment is created, and your action has been added and published, you’re ready to build a custom Joule Skill that calls the required API from your service. 

These skills will be reusable and can later be connected to an intelligent agent in Part 2 of this series.

Create a New Skill Project 

  1. Open Joule Studio in SAP Build. 
  2. Click on create > Create Skill  
  3. Enter 
    • Project Name: eg., Intelligent Maintenance Order Stock Validation Agent   
    • Description: e.g., Skills to validate whether maintenance orders can be fulfilled based on stock availability
  4. Note: While we’re only creating Joule Skills in this post, we’ll use the same project to add and configure the Joule Agent in Part 2 of this series.
  5. Click Review > Create 

Once the project is created, you’ll be taken to the Overview tab, where you’ll see the project name and description. 

 

 

The project will be created after you click “Create”.  

Add a New Joule Skill 

  1. In the project, click Create 
  2. From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  3. Fill in: 
    • Name: e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 
    • Identifier: e.g., get-maintenance-order 
    • Description: e.g., get list of a maintenance order  
    • Click Create 

 

 

Add the Parameters to the Skill 

  1. Open the skill by clicking its name or the arrow icon to the left .This is the panel where you need to add input, output parameters.  
  2. In the “General” tab, update the name/description of the Joule skill. 
  3. Keep the toggle “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” ON (so the skill can be started directly by the user, not just via an agent).

     

  4. Go to the Parameters tab. Click Configure to add input and output parameters. 
  5. Inputs allow Joule to collect user input in the conversation interface. 
  6. Outputs define what information will be shown to the user after the skill executes. Add the input parameter: 

➕Add Input 

  1. Add the following Input: 
    • Name: User query 
    • Description: Context for the endpoint to give the list of the orders 
    • Required: Unchecked 
    • Click Apply to save the input. 

➕Add Output 

  1. Add the following Output: 
    • Name: List of Orders 
    • Type: Any 
    • List: Checked 
    • Required: Checked 
    • Description: List of orders depending on the user request (e.g., pending or open orders) 
  2. Click Apply to save the output. 
  3. Output types can vary — choose the appropriate type based on the structure of your API response. 
  4. You’ve now configured both input and output parameters for your Joule skill. 

Add an Action Step to the Skill 

  1. Click the ➕Plus icon to add a step
    1.  
  2. Select Call Action 
  3. In the Action search: 
    • Either browse all actions 
    • Or use the search bar to quickly find your previously published action (e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails) 
    • Click Add 

 

 

 

Configure the Action Step 

  1. After adding the action, you’ll see General, Input, and Output tabs. 
  2. In the General tab: 
    • Set Step Name: Get maintenance orders 
    • For Destination Variable, create or select one (e.g., Fulfillment_agent) 
    • Click Create to add the destination, then select it. 
  3. Go to the Input tab and map the input (e.g., user query). 
  4. In the Output tab, you can view the API’s response schema. 
  5. Click End to configure the skill’s outputs and map the expected output value. 
  6. Click Save to finish the step configuration. 

 

 

Create Skills for Each API Endpoint 

We have already created a skill which uses GET/MaintenanceOrder  

 

Tool Name 

Endpoint 

Description 

GetMaintenanceOrders 

GET /MaintenanceOrder 

Retrieve all maintenance orders (can be filtered) 

GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}') 

Get details of a specific maintenance order 

cGetOrderOperations 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}')/operation 

List operations under a maintenance order 

GetOperationComponents 

GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

List components for a specific operation 

GetMaterialDetails 

GET /Material('{ID}') 

Get material details 

GetMaterialStockLevels 

GET /Material('{ID}')/stockLevel 

Check stock availability for a material 

 

For each skill, remember to: 

  • Configure input and output parameters.
  • Set the correct destination variable.
  • Turn on “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” if creating Joule Skills.

Tip: Use the Action Definition to Configure Skill Parameters 

When configuring the Skill Input and Skill Output, you don’t need to guess what the API expects or returns. 

You can find this information directly from the Action definition you uploaded earlier: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions.
  2. Open the Action project you created .
  3. Select the relevant endpoint.
  4. Navigate to the Input and Output tabs 

From there, you can: 

  • See which input parameters are required 
  • Understand the expected output structure and data types 

 

 

 

 

Example: For GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

  • Input: ID of the operation (marked with a red asterisk = required) .
  • Output: 
    • value → A list of components (type: list) 
    • count → Number of items (type: number) 

Use this information to accurately define the parameters in your Joule Skill > Parameters tab. 

  

Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills 

With your Joule Skills created and configured, the next step is to release and deploy them to your environment so they can be used in real scenarios.

  1. Click Release to version your Project.

  

       2. Go to Project > Versions 

       3. Click Deploy 

 

 

During deployment: 

  1. Select the Environment created in Step 2 (e.g., Joule Studio demo) 
  2. Select the Destination you added in Step 3 
    • You will only see destinations that are: 
      • Associated with this environment 
      • Or made available to All Environments 
  3. Click Deploy 
  4. After deployment, the agent status will appear as Active 

 

 

 

Test the Skills in Joule Studio

To interact with your the skills: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Environments 
  2. Click your environment (e.g., joule studio demo) 
  3. Under your agent project, click More > Joule 
  4. Click Launch to open the Joule Chat window 

You can now start chatting with your agent using real-world prompts. 

 

For example: 


Debugging Agents Flow 

  • You can open the Debug Panel in the top right corner to see details of how Joule selects the skills based on the user input.  

Example Prompts to Test the Joule skills

  1. “Show me all current maintenance orders” 
  2. “Get details for maintenance order 25” 
  3. “What operations are planned for maintenance order 4?” 
  4. “What is the description of material 19” 
  5. “How many units of material M-45678 are in stock?” 

Wrapping Up Part 1: Skills First, Intelligence Next

In this first part of our Joule Studio blog series, we focused on building the foundation: creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills that interact with maintenance orders and material data. These skills are now live, testable, and ready to be reused across various automation and intelligence layers.

Each skill is designed to handle a focused task — whether it’s fetching order details, retrieving stock levels, or listing required components. With these deployed, you're now ready to take the next leap: combining them into an intelligent agent.

In Part 2, we’ll build a Joule Agent that brings your deployed skills together into an intelligent assistant — one that can understand maintenance-related questions, check if orders can be fulfilled, identify what’s blocking them, and even suggest solutions such as replenishment needs or follow-up actions.


Part 2 will show you how to build an intelligent maintenance agent that brings your skills to life — stay tuned!

If you're interested in diving deeper into Joule Studio and expanding your knowledge beyond this use case, here are valuable resources to accelerate your learning:

Learning Resources

  • Learning Journey - Comprehensive guided learning path for Joule Studio
  • Documentation - Official technical documentation and reference guides
  • Discovery Center Mission - Hands-on missions to build practical skills
  • Joule Studio Tutorials - Step-by-step development tutorials
  • Architecture Overview - Technical architecture and integration patterns
  • Smart Advisory Companion – Inspiration Video - See Joule Studio in action with real-world scenarios

These resources will help you explore additional use cases, advanced features, and best practices for building intelligent automation solutions with Joule Studio.

entry.title: SAP Joule for Beginners: Everything You Need to Know - All at one stop!
entry.content:
This blog is for anyone in the SAP domain — from consultants to architects — who is curious about SAP Joule and wants to understand how it works. You're in the right place!

Disclaimer: This blog is based on publicly available information as of 24th July 2025, along with my personal interpretation. Sources of all referenced information, where available, are quoted in the REFERENCE section of this blog.

Topics covered in this blog are:

Welcome to the world of SAP Joule! Let's decode it into chunks! 

"How can I help you? 

Talk to me naturally. For example, 'What are my task for today?"

 

This is how Joule greets you in first place!

Joule — a name derived from the unit of energy — is here to energize our business processes, save valuable time, and simplify even the most tedious tasks resulting in greater efficiency and a noticeable uplift in the quality of our work.

SECTION 1: Understanding key terminologies and concepts:

Let’s cover some basic artificial intelligence terms before diving deeper into Joule for better understanding.

  • Artificial intelligence (AI) is a technology that mimics human reasoning and behavior, enabling machines to make decisions on their own. By processing large volumes of data, AI can understand speech, identify patterns and trends, solve problems proactively, and forecast future outcomes.

  • GenAI also known as generative AI is a model where it can create new content which can either be text, image, audio and video based on the existing content that it already has.

  • LLM (Large language Model) is the specific model (like GPT, PaLM, LLaMA) that powers the text generation part of GenAI. It is a type of artificial intelligence model that is trained to understand and generate human-like language. It's designed to read, summarize, translate, predict, or generate text based on the input it receives. Eg, When we ask ChatGPT a question, it's an LLM that's interpreting our text and generating a relevant, natural-sounding response.

  • AI copilot is a virtual assistant that helps business application users complete tasks more easily through a conversational interface. It uses generative AI to understand requests, take actions, and offer insights from business data. AI Copilots use LLMs to understand natural language and assist users in real time.The answer that is provided to the user is limited to training data against LLMs. "Large" refers to the massive amount of data and the billions of parameters the model is trained on.

  • Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): In SAP world, customer specific data cannot be used to train the LLMs. And hence we need a better way to retrieve the desired outcomes without breaching the customer's data privacy. This is where RAG comes into picture. It is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). This is done through Document Grounding. As a part of preparation of RAG, it provided with SAP and customer specific documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are then chunked into smaller parts and are then embedded into dense, continuous vectors—known as embeddings—which represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query. This information is passed to the LLM as prompts during runtime rather than getting it trained. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data. Rather, they get Grounded against customer specific data. 

  • HANA Vector Database enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords.

    Image source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uiv29xYlXvQ

  • For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. For instance, when a user asks about their company's paternity leave policy, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.

SECTION 2: What is SAP Joule and what are its use cases in the SAP world

SAP Joule is an AI copilot from SAP. Powered by SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), it serves as a virtual assistant that leverages generative AI to understand and respond to user requests within SAP systems.

Before diving deeper, Let's understand some of the use cases of SAP Joule. Below are some of the end-user prompts that can be sent to Joule, where it responds appropriately using natural language processing. These examples are sourced from SAP's official Joule product pages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html#agility-for-all

Why Joule?

Joule is SAP domain-specific and is integrated with SAP’s suite of products, ensuring seamless interaction and data exchange across the SAP portfolio. It is also a responsible AI solution, with a strong emphasis on industry-specific regulations and standards. As a result, Joule is a more Relevant, Reliable, and Responsible AI copilot for SAP.

As specified earlier, the LLMs in Joule are not actually trained to respond to SAP user queries. Instead, Joule use document grounding through RAGe (Retrieval-Augmented Generation for enterprise) for unstructured data, and the SAP Knowledge Graph for structured data, enabling it to provide more comprehensive responses by referencing business documents from both SAP and third-party repositories , while LLMs are used to add natural language rather than the actual context in the response that is sent to user by Joule. That is, Grounding uses a customer’s own knowledge sources (e.g., travel policies, enablement content, service manuals, FAQs, etc.) to supplement the capabilities of Large language models (LLMs). This gives Joule a unique understanding of SAP data and processes, allowing it to respond more reliably than any other AI copilot.

Joule is seamlessly integrated into various SAP cloud solutions to help users work more efficiently across different business functions, such as:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition

  • SAP SuccessFactors

  • SAP Ariba

  • SAP Sales Cloud

  • SAP Customer Experience solutions

  • SAP Concur

  • SAP ABAP Cloud

However, it is worth noting that Joule is not available for on-premise solutions.

Thus the main advantages of SAP Joule include:

  • Enhanced decision-making

  • Accelerated end-to-end business processes

  • Personalized UI with inherited user authorizations

  • Advanced analytics

  • Contextual awareness

  • Ability to meet diverse business needs

Business application supported by SAP Joule:

SAP Joule runs on the AI Foundation of SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and supports a wide range of business application such as Finance, Procurement, Supply Chain, Human Resources, Sales and Services, Marketing and E-Commerce, Development, and Consulting.  Apart from some of the use cases described before, a detailed list of business use cases are available through URL => https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/use-cases.html

Joule's interaction pattern:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html

Joule's interaction pattern can vary from:

  1. Informational: The Joule provides answers to factual questions (e.g. "What are the key rules for a team outing?")

  2. Navigational: The Joule guides users through a multi-step process or an internal journey, like approving a request or changing organizational data. (e.g. “Where in the app do I send a promotion request?”)

  3. Transactional: The Joule engages in task completion workflows, e.g. reviewing and updating position details (job title, department, cost center), then confirming by saying “Done”. It also supports user edits and next steps before finalizing. (e.g. “Update the position title to Sustainability Supply Chain Consultant — ready to submit?”)

  4. Analytical: The Joule offers data insights, metrics, and visual analytics, such as attrition trends vs. hiring rates charted by quarter. It helps users interpret numbers and trends. (e.g.“What was our quarterly attrition rate in 2024?”)

SECTION 3: Joule architecture

Image source: Joule learning journey 

Joule architecture consists of key components which work together to respond to a user's question.

  1. Scenario Catalog: The Scenario Catalog holds information about all the available scenarios, functions, and skills in SAP cloud applications. In helps to distinguish between different user questions and guides Joule to understand the request and connect it to the right action or system or workflow. This acts like a blueprint that maps user queries to the appropriate actions, destinations, or logic within SAP systems. For example, if a user query is "Retrieves the current leave balance for a given employee", then this gets mapped as below:
    1. Scenario: 'Get_Employee_Leave_Balance'
    2. Business application : Human Resource
    3. 'leave balance': Employee ID, leave Type and Date Range.
  2. Knowledge Catalog: This contains SAP-knowledge as well as the customer-owned knowledge. It is a collection of documents and content sources (often unstructured or semi-structured) that are made available to Joule for question-answering using RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) techniques. It supports Joule in answering open-ended, natural language questions that aren’t directly tied to structured data or APIs. For example, it can have a company's HR policies (e.g., leave, travel, benefits), Finance guidelines (e.g., expense reimbursement rules) and so on. These documents are chunked and vectorized using embeddings in HANA vector database as specified earlier. When a user asks a related question, Joule retrieves relevant chunks and sends them to the LLM to generate a grounded answer.
  3. User Context: This helps joule to contextualize a user's question. This includes information about the SAP cloud applications the user is currently using, along with any additional SAP applications the customer has licensed and activated for use with Joule. Joule also recognizes the user’s roles and permissions, ensuring they can access only the information or perform the actions they are authorized to within the SAP cloud environment. Additionally, Joule takes into account the user’s chat history and context to provide most relevant and accurate responses to user queries. To put in other words, a user will be able to view or perform any tasks only if they are authorized to do so based on their existing authorization. 
  4. Document Grounding: Large Language Models (LLMs) are generally capable of understanding prompts and generating human-like responses. However, they often lack the context and specificity needed for business scenarios. To address this, Joule uses a technique called document grounding. This allows Joule to generate more accurate and relevant responses by referencing business documents stored in SAP and third-party repositories. As part of document grounding, customers can upload their own content (such as HR policies, travel policies, service manuals, etc.). When an end user asks a question, Joule searches these documents for relevant information and returns a concise, natural-language response, including the source references. This ensures the answers are grounded in the customer's own structured and unstructured data, making them more trustworthy and context-aware.
  5.  Grounding: This is the process of combining generative LLMs with advanced information retrieval techniques to enhance the accuracy and relevance of responses—without the need to train or fine-tune the model on company-specific data. It leverages a customer’s internal knowledge sources (e.g., policies, FAQs, training material) to supplement the LLM’s existing knowledge. This improves the model’s reliability and ensures that responses reflect the customer’s unique business context.
  6. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): RAG is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). As part of the RAG, Document Grounding is performed. In this step, RAG is provided with relevant documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are chunked into smaller parts and then embedded into dense, continuous vectors—known as embeddings—which represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query.
  7.  HANA Vector Database: It enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords. For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. When a user asks about their leave balance, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.
  8.  Knowledge Graph: This graph is a semantic network that connects entities (like customers, products, orders, employees, etc.) and defines how they are related. This helps Joule go beyond keyword matching or document lookup. It actually lets Joule "understand" business context and structure.  Joule uses the graph to understand how different entities are linked (e.g., “Employee X belongs to Department Y” or “Invoice A is tied to Purchase Order B”). With this, Joule disambiguate questions and provide more accurate answers.  It also enables logical inferences, like “Show me all open invoices for suppliers in Germany”, “List products related to a delayed shipment” etc. Even if the data is spread across multiple systems, the graph can link them together efficiently.

 

 

Image sources: Knowledge Graph or Vector Database… Which is Better? and  GraphRAG: The Marriage of Knowledge Graphs and RAG: Emil Eifrem

NOTE: While RAG brings in document-based context and vector search finds the right text chunks, the Knowledge Graph brings in structure and relationship-based logic. Eg: RAG may find a document about a purchase policy, but the Knowledge Graph helps determine which department owns that policy and who can approve it.

Does LLM gets trained with SAP's data?

When SAP’s AI assistant Joule interacts with a Large Language Model (LLM), it doesn’t send data for storage or training. Instead, it shares information only briefly, as part of a prompt during runtime. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time, but it doesn’t remember or learn from what it receives. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data.

Joule's orchestration layer:

Image source: Examining how to onboard and extend Joule | AI105

Steps involved within Joule for processing user query:

  1. User submits query in natural language via Joule client in SAP cloud apps
  2. The prompt is sent to the Dialogue Management system, which manages the conversation flow and understands the user's intent.
  3. The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) service forms a semantic vector search query based on the user input.
  4. This query is executed against a Vector Database where document embeddings are stored. The relevant document extracts are retrieved. These embeddings were created earlier from company-specific or SAP documents using document grounding
  5. The retrieved document snippets are passed along with the original prompt to a Large Language Model. The LLM uses the relevant extracts to ground its response (ensuring the response is based on actual documents, not hallucinations).
  6. The LLM generates a natural-language answer, grounded in the retrieved documents.
  7. The final answer is displayed to the user with source links and supporting documents attached.->Example: A link to a company travel policy PDF is shown under “Source Document”.

entry.title: Build Shipment Creation and Tracking Skill using Joule Studio integrated with SAP BN4L GTT
entry.content:
As we know by now, Joule is SAP’s generative AI copilot that helps users interact with business data and processes in a conversational, natural language format. With Joule Studio, developers and business users alike can create custom Joule skills to address specific business scenarios, extending the power of SAP Business AI.

With the latest launch of Joule Studio, we can now build custom AI agents and skills that automate workflows and improve efficiency in executing routine tasks. Joule Studio is currently live with the Skill builder and the Agent Builder is slated to be GA later this year. 

Earlier this year, I had the privilege to work with the Joule Studio product teams to build and test Logistics Agents for providing transportation options, fetching weather forecasts on transportation routes and tracking with carriers in real-time.

In this article, we will walk through the steps on how to build Joule Skills for Logistics and Transportation use cases using Joule Studio. These custom skills will help users create a shipment directly in SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) and subsequently track that shipment’s status using Global Track and Trace (GTT) using the Joule digital assistant.

This is particularly useful for transportation planners, customer service reps, and warehouse operators who want a quick and intelligent way to interact with shipment data in natural language - without navigating through multiple systems. Furthermore, once the Joule is activated in S/4HANA systems or SAP Build Workzone then Joule can create shipments directly in BN4L GTT using the data from ERP orders/deliveries. 

Step 1: Prerequisites

Before building the skill in Joule Studio, ensure you have activated the following:

  • Joule Studio on your SAP BTP subaccount. (refer provisioning Joule Studio)

  • SAP Business Network for Logistics tenant with API access. 

  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub to reference GTT APIs. 

  • Authentication credentials for SAP BN4L API endpoints. 

  • Developer role and permissions to create skills in Joule Studio.   

 

Step 2: Design the Skill in Joule Studio

Login to your SAP Build lobby to create a Joule Skill. 

Skill to Create Shipment in BN4L GTT

Step 1: Create a new Joule skill and provide a valid description which will help as the trigger mechanism. Add input parameters to the skills to capture Source Location, Destination Location, Pickup Date, Shipment No, etc. 

We can even make this optimizer this step further by fetching an ERP delivery data from a S/4HANA System using the Odata Service. With that Joule will be able to fetch the delivery details to create a shipment. However, to understand how the conversations work, we can proceed with capturing data from the user.  

Step 2: Create and Publish a Build Action from Build Lobby to integrate your BN4L GTT tenant with SAP Build. 
Here, we can use the GTT Write Service API (Shipment Event) which creates a shipment in GTT (For more info visit SAP Help)

Step 3: Add the published Action to Joule Skill and map the Skill input to Action input. 

Step 4 (Optional): Add Send Message function to display a successful shipment creation message to the User along with a hyperlink to navigate GTT shipment to v. 

Step 5: Deploy and Test the Joule Skill using the Build Environments. Currently, Joule Studio supports testing the custom Joule Skills only from within an Environment. Under Joule, launch the standalone Joule Digital Assistant. 

 

Step 3: Joule digital assistant (the conversation part) 

Use Joule digital assistant to test the skill that we just deployed. Open the logs to review the steps performed by Joule to execute a Skill based on user input. 

Create a shipment conversation with basic shipment information. 

 

Skill to Track Shipment using BN4L GTT

Step 1:  Return to SAP Build Lobby and open your project, within the project create a new Joule Skill. Remember to add a wholesome description. Add input - trackingId and output parameters -status, city, region. 

Step 2: Add a new Build Action to fetch shipment status from GTT. To find more details of the GTT Read services in the BN4L GTT Reference Guide.

Release and Publish the Action to be used in Joule Skill. 

Refer to the SAP BPA help to learn more on how to use $filter capability while querying using an Odata service. 

Step 3: Add this Action as a step function in the Track Shipment Joule Skill. Map the Action input to the Skills Input to pass the tracking number from the user as a query parameter to the GTT read service. This will improve the overall performance and response time of Joule during runtime conversations. 

Create a new destination variable to represent the GET service BTP destination. 

Step 4: In the End step, map the Skills Output to the corresponding fields from the Action Output result. This will enable Joule to form a logical output based on the message to be displayed to the user.  

Step 5:  Release and deploy the skill to the same Environment created for the first skill. 

Step 6: Navigate to the Environment, now you should be able to see the latest version of the Project deployed. Launch the Joule DA from the Joule tab. 

Step 3: Joule digital assistant (the conversation part) 

Track the shipment with Shipment ID to view the execution status and the current location. 

Step 4: Integrate Joule with SAP Build Workzone

Enable your users to interact with Joule and enjoy these custom skills by activating Joule in SAP Build Workzone.  

Final Thoughts

This is an high level overview on building custom Joule Skills for deterministic tasks based on business processes expanding the horizon of SAP Business AI. With Joule Studio, we are now able to extend SAP Joule's AI capabilities to address unique business needs. 

Learn more about how SAP Premium Engagement can help you accelerate your digital transformation with curated AI workshops and discovery sessions. 

SAP Business AI Joule SAP Business Network for Logistics SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition @SAPMaxAttention

entry.title: Joule Studioがリリースされたので早速CAPアプリを自然言語で操作するカスタムスキルを構築してみた
entry.content:
はじめに

先日、SAP Buildに新たに Joule Studio が加わりました。これは、自然言語によってエンドユーザーの業務操作を支援する「Joule 」のカスタムスキルをノーコードベースで開発できるサービスです。このJoule Studioではカスタムスキルとカスタムエージェントの構築ができる予定ですが、現段階でリリースされている機能はカスタムスキルの構築のみです。

本記事では、SAP BTPで提供される開発フレームワークである CAP（Cloud Application Programming Model） で構築した書籍管理アプリケーションをベースに、Joule Studioを用いて「書籍IDから情報を取得するカスタムスキル」を構築するプロセスをご紹介します。

ゴールは下記のような形です。

  • ユーザーがJouleに「201番の本の詳細を教えて」と話しかけると、CAPアプリのODataエンドポイントから該当データを取得し、回答できるようにすること。

 

ステップ①：CAPアプリケーションの準備

プロジェクト作成とサンプル追加

まずは SAP Build Code にて、Full-Stack Cloud Applicationプロジェクトを作成します。

ターミナルを起動したのち、下記コマンドにより、Bookshopサンプル（Books, Authors, Genresなど）をプロジェクトに追加します。

cds add sample

これにより、BookShopアプリケーションで利用するデータモデルやロジック、サンプルデータなどがプロジェクトの中に追加されます。

MTA構成の有効化とサービス定義確認



次に、SAP BTP環境にデプロイを行うために、下記のコマンドを実行します。

cds add mta

これにより Multi Target Application（MTA）構成を追加することができます。ファイルとしては、mta.yamlなどが追加されます。

このアプリケーションのCatalogServiceとAdminServiceの定義を確認してみましょう。CatalogServiceではBookなどに関するデータの閲覧ができたり、注文発注の関数が定義されていたり、という構成が確認できます。

一方、AdminServiceの側にはロール制御（@requires: 'admin'）が設定されています。これにより、BooksやAuthorsのデータモデルの編集処理はadminというロールを持ったユーザーのみが行えるように構成されています。

セキュリティとモックデータの準備

そして、そのロールは xs-security.json というファイルに定義されています。下記のコマンドを実行することで、Role TemplateがService定義に基づいて追加され、アプリケーションをデプロイした際に同時にロールが定義されてSAP BTP Cockpitから操作できるようになります。

cds compile srv/ --to xsuaa > xs-security.json

また、dataディレクトリの中にはモックデータも追加されています。このデータは、デプロイ時には SAP HANA Cloud へ自動的に初期データとして追加されます。

デプロイ前に、一度プレビューしてみましょう。cds watch というコマンドでプレビューサーバーを立ち上げることができます。

/odata/v4/catalog/Books

上記のODataエンドポイントにアクセスすると、データが返ってくることが確認できます。

問題なければ、ビルドを行いましょう。下記のコマンドで .mtar ファイルを作成します。

mbt build

 

ステップ②：SAP BTP環境へのデプロイと設定

アプリケーションのデプロイと確認

作成された .mtar ファイル を右クリックし、Deploy MTA Application ボタンをクリックします。

無事に Cloud Foundry環境にデプロイが完了すると、アプリケーションが正常に起動していることをSAP BTP Cockpit上で確認することができます。

XSUAAロールとDestinationの構成

同じく、アプリケーションのRoleタブを開くとデプロイされたロールも確認可能です。

定義済みのadminロールをカスタムで作成したロールコレクションに割り当て、権限を必要とする対象ユーザーに付与しておきましょう。ただし、今回は簡単な検証をするだけなのでこのロールベースアクセスは扱いません。

それでは次に、JouleのカスタムスキルからCAPにアクセスさせる際のDestinationを定義します。作成にあたり、CAPのアクセスに必要な認証情報（サービスキー）を作成します。

これに基づき、下記の通り OAuth2 Client Credentials方式でDestinationを構成します。
下記の通り、間違えのないように記載してください。

項目

値

URL

デプロイしたアプリケーションのURL + /odata/v4/catalog

Authentication

OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID

サービスキーのuaa.clientId

Client Secret

サービスキーのuaa.clientSecret

TokenService URL

サービスキーのuaa.url + /oauth/token

下記のプロパティも忘れずに設定するようにしてください。

プロパティ名

値

sap.processautomation.enabled

true

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled

true

sap.build.usage

CAP

それでは、ここからは SAP Build の設定に入ってきます。SAP Build側にもSAP BTP Cockpit 側で定義したDestinationをインポートし、API接続の準備を整えていきます。



ステップ③：CAP APIをJouleアクションとして公開

Actionの定義とデプロイ

それではJoule Studioで構築するカスタムスキル内で外部APIへの接続時に利用するActionを作成していきます。

アクション作成画面に入ると、CAPアプリケーションを選択します。その後、先ほど登録したCAPアプリのODataエンドポイント（BookShopSample_CatalogAPI）を選択します。これにより、CAPのODataのメタデータを自動的に読み取り、そのAPIに用意されたエンドポイントを自動で読み取ることができます。

必要なアクションを選択し、テスト → リリース → パブリッシュまでを行います。今回はBooksエンティティなどのアクションを選択しています。今回のブログの範囲では、この中でもBooksをIDに基づいて取得するアクションを使っていきます。

 

ここまでは今まで SAP Build からアクションを使って外部APIを呼び出す際には同じようにやっていたことですね。さて、ここからが新しくリリースされた部分になります！

 

ステップ④：Joule Skills の作成

スキルプロジェクトの作成と設定

「BookShopSample_Skills」というスキルプロジェクトを作成し、まずは getBookFromBookShopByID スキルを作成します。
（画像ではlistBooksスキルを作っていますが、よしなにスキルを作成してみてください）

他にも色々な形のスキルを追加してみてください。それぞれのスキルについて、デプロイ前に何かしらの処理が定義されていなければならないため、ミニマムでお試しされる方は getBookFromBookShopByID のみ定義すればOKです。

ステップ⑤：スキルの内部構成（Get Book by ID）

スキルにActionを組み込む

前ステップで公開したアクションプロジェクトから「Get entity from Books by key」アクションをスキル内に追加します。

BookID入力の受け取りと変換

次に、このアクションは本のIDを引数として要求するので、Joule Skillの入力引数を定義し、それをアクションに渡す設定を行います。この際に、現段階の仕様ではスキルの入力引数はText型に固定されているようなため、Formulaを用いて、アクションが受け付けるNumber型に変更する必要があります。

ユーザーへの応答構成

次に、ユーザーへ表示するコンポーネントを構成します。Send Message コンポーネントを追加し、アクションからの返り値を渡していきます。具体的には、取得した書籍データ（タイトル・価格・在庫）を「イラスト付きメッセージ」で視覚的に表示します。

 

ステップ⑥：スキルのデプロイとJouleからの呼び出し

お疲れさまでした、これで設定は完了です！それでは早速、このスキルをデプロイしていきましょう。

環境へのデプロイとDestinationマッピング

作成したスキルを任意のSAP Build Process Automationの環境（例：PlayGround1）にデプロイし、Destinationとの関連付けを行います。この際、サンセットが予定されているPublic環境はデプロイ先として指定できません。必ず新規に作成したShared環境を使うようにしてください。

なお、環境の詳細な情報や作成方法は下記SAP Help Portalをご参照ください。

https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/environments?locale=ja-JP

動作検証（英語・日本語）

それでは、デプロイされたスキルを呼び出していきましょう。Joule Studioでは、カスタムスキルを検証するためのJouleが分離された形で用意されています。このJouleには、下記の通りアクセスすることが可能です。

Launch ボタンをクリックすると、全画面でJouleが表示されます。早速聞いてみましょう。

Joule に対して自然言語で 201番の本の詳細を教えて、などの内容を入力すると、正しく応答が返ってくることを確認できました。今回はIDからの詳細取得のみを実装していますが、同様にスキル定義を追加していくことで、様々な角度から詳細を取得していくことができるようになるはずです。

例えば、Send Message モジュールにも色々な形があり、例えばリストを扱うようなlistBooksを実装すると下記のようになります。

是非他にも色々と触ってみていただければと思います！

おわりに

今回の構成では、CAP で構築した OData API を SAP Build および Joule Studio と統合し、ユーザーが自然言語で業務処理を実行できる仕組みをノーコードで構築することができました。

今後は今回作成した「取得系」のスキルに加えて、「登録」「更新」「集計」などの対話型業務オペレーションを拡張していくことで、より実践的な業務アシスタントを構築できると考えられます。まだまだリリースされたばかりの機能ですが、今後の機能拡張に是非ご期待ください！

entry.title: Get SAP-Certified in Low-Code/No-Code Development: What You Need to Know
entry.content:
SAP offers a certification for Low-Code/No-Code developers, specifically focused on SAP Build. For those working in enterprise development or considering how to extend their skill set into more agile application delivery, this certification validates your ability to design, develop, and automate processes with minimal or no coding.

 

Why It Matters
SAP Build tools are increasingly integral to business process transformation. The certification covers:

  • SAP Build Apps – application development using declarative logic and reusable components.
  • SAP Build Work Zone – centralized workspaces integrating apps, content, and tasks.
  • SAP Build Process Automation – visual tools for workflows, business rules, and bots.

Even experienced developers can benefit from mastering these platforms to complement traditional development approaches, especially for rapid prototyping and business-led innovation.

 

The Certification Path

 

  1. Self-Guided Learning Journeys
  • SAP Build Apps: Learn how to design front-end interfaces, bind data sources, and configure logic flows — all without code.
  • SAP Build Work Zone: Understand workspace creation, content integration, and personalization.
  • SAP Build Process Automation: Gain skills in workflow design, rule configuration, and automation bot setup.
  1. Practical Application: A guided, end-to-end hands-on exercise simulates real-world scenarios. This is a required step before taking the certification and ensures applied learning.
  2. Certification Exam: Once ready, schedule the exam to validate your LCNC expertise within the SAP ecosystem.

 

Extend Your Learning and Network

 

  • Watch SAP Developer Advocates on YouTube for advanced tutorials and use cases.
  • Attend SAP CodeJam events for collaborative learning.
  • Subscribe to SAP Learning Hub for deeper, structured content.

This certification isn’t just about earning a badge — it’s a way to stay current with SAP’s evolving platform and expand how you deliver value.

entry.title: step by step guide for using Governance Rule to control transport in SAP Build
entry.content:
Now SAP Build allows users to create Governance Rules from templates, and use the predefined processes to control the creation and transport of their projects.

In this blog post we will look at how to implement it. We will start by setting up Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) to enable the transport between SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) tenants, and then continue with adding governance rule in SAP Build to set an approval gateway before the content goes to Transport Management Service. 

 

The following articles are mainly referred to:

  • [SAP Help Portal] Configure Governance Rules https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/configure-governance-rules?locale=en-US
  • [SAP Help Portal] Documentation of the integration with SAP Cloud Transport Management: Transport a Project
  • [SAP Help Portal] SAP Content Agent Service https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/create-target-node-destination
  • [SAP Blog] Transporting content in SAP BUILD Process Automation https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/transporting-content-in-sap-build-process-automation/bc-p/13556499
  • [SAP Blog] Configure Governance Rules in SAP Build https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/configure-governance-rules-in-sap-build/ba-p/14133093
  • [SAP Developers YouTube channel video] Set Up Rules for Who Can Create and Transport SAP Build Projects https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLJTpAwYxyM&t=9s

Prerequisites:

  • You have a source SBPA tenant, and a target SBPA tenant (application subscription), and you have access to them and their Subaccounts.
  • You have subscription to cTMS tenant and you have access to it and its Subaccount.

Step 1: create service instances and their destinations

If you have not set up Transport for SBAP, you will need to start with creating several service instances and their destinations. If you are already able to transport contents from one SBPA tenant to another, then you can skip the first three steps and directly go to Step 4. 

This allow cTMS and SBPA to talk to each other via CAS. CAS is always free. 

The architecture will eventually look like: 

Step 1.1 create service instance and service key for cTMS

In the same Subaccount of cTMS subscription, create a service instance and service key, see Steps to use Transport Management using Programmatic Access (API Remote Call).

 

Step 1.2: create Content Agent Service (CAS) instances in source and target subaccounts

In the Subaccount of source and target SBPA, a CAS's service instance need to be created, choose Standard Plan and Assemble role for this plan in the creation wizard.  A service key need to be created. https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/initial-setup

 

Step 1.3: create destinations for Content Agent Service (CAS) instances

And then, in the subaccount of cTMS, create transport destination Create Transport Destinations pointing to the CAS of source and target SAP BTP subaccounts.

 

Step 2: create a route with the source and target nodes

Step 2.1: create route in cTMS

With the source and target CAS created, you can now go to cTMS, create a route, with source and target nodes using the destinations that you created for the source and targeted CAS. For details about how to create nodes and routes, you can use route wizard to create one route and two nodes in one minute, details please check: 

  • create transport node Create Transport Nodes. Create transport nodes as representations of the source and target end points of deployment processes in your landscape. Add configuration details as required.
  • create transport route Create Transport Routes. In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

 

Please note that the content type for process automation in SBPA is MTA, as listed here https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-transport-management/sap-cloud-transport-management/supported-content-types?locale=en-US 

example:

Step 2.2: create TransportManagementService destination 

And then, with the source node name, you can go to the source SBPA subaccount, and create a destination named TransportManagementService, pointing to the cTMS service instance, and specify the property to source node. This will allow you to perform Export from Content Agent UI, SAP Integration Suite UI, or SAP Build. Details see https://help.sap.com/docs/content-agent-service/user-guide/create-transportmanagementservice-destination

 

Step 2.3: add destination to SBPA source 

Now you can go to your source SBPA, in the control tower, you can add the TransportManagementService destination you created for cTMS service instance.

Step 3: Test the transport in SBPA

You can now test with the transport feature in SBPA.

Choose a project in SBPA, choose a release version, click the …, click Transport. 

In the source node, you need to choose the source node you created in the transport route in cTMS, and then give your description of the transport (if there are descriptions in your project, it will be automatically written). Then you can click Transport to start the process. 

The transport content will be packed as MTA to your cTMS source node, and you will see the tag “Transported” in your project release after success.

In your cTMS, you will see that your source node has transport event as succeeded. 

But in target node, you will need to first approve the transport request and then the content will be transported to your target SBPA. 

After succeeded, you can go to the target SBPA, and import the content as a project. First you will notice that there is a red notification icon displayed by import button, and then you click into it, you will find the available content. Choose it and click import, you will find it created as a project and you are the member of the project. 

This means that the transport of SBPA content via cTMS works.

Then you go to the second half of the post, to add the governance rule to transport.

Step 4: Create service instance, key, destination for source SBPA

Create a service instance and service key for source SAP Build Process Automation. See https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/configure-governance-rules?locale=en-US

Then create a destination pointing to the SBPA service instance you just created, using the authentication type of OAuth2UserTokenExchange. This is where a token representing one user (e.g., a JWT from XSUAA) is exchanged for another token for the same user but for a different audience or scope. This is crucial in multi-tier applications where a service needs to call another service, maintaining the original user's identity.

Remember to add a property to the destination: sap.processautomation.enabled=true.

Also add the destination to the source SBPA's control tower:

Step 5: enable the Governance Rule for Transport

In SBPA's control tower, Governance Rules, find the template to create the governance rule for transport.

When you click into the process of the newly created project, you will see the approval flow, and you can adjust it. By default, there is a questionnaire sent to the person who trigger the transport process, and then the filled out questionnaire will be sent for the same person (can be adjusted to your need) for approval.

You will need to release it, deploy it in the environment of Governance, and to the destination you just created for the source SBPA service instance:

And last but not least, you go back to the control tower, governance rule, and enable it for transport:

You can also do the same for project creation.

Step 5: Test it with transport

In lobby, find a project to transport. You will need to choose a released version of it, and in the transport dialog that opens, enter the description and choose the source node.

You will see that the status of the release turns into “complete transport questionnaire” (it will change according to which step you are in the transport governance rule process). The popout window reminds you of a pending questionnaire, and you can go to the questionnaire from here or in the My Inbox.

Next step is to complete the questionnaire:

And approve the questionnaire:

And then the content will be transport by CAS to the source node in cTMS, and the rest of the steps will be familiar to you.

Approve in target node:

Go to the target SBPA and you will find the content transported there:

In the source SPBA, you can check the past transport requests in control tower:

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
After this post was written, with the help of the wonderful community, we came up with a different, and in most ways, better solution for this issue. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/triggering-process-in-shared-environment-from-sap-build-apps-better/ba-p/14183502.

But what's written in this blog is still valuable, because it will show you how to use the relatively new flow function HTTP Destination Request, which lets you easily and still with a good amount of control call APIs using destinations.

Unfortunately, the Processes flow functions to trigger processes from SAP Build Apps (for now) do not work for shared environments. And since the public environment is deprecated, that means they essentially no longer work at all.  Hopefully this will be modified soon.

In the meantime, here's how to work around that issue.

The Issue

I am not sure but I assume the issue is that when you make an API call to trigger a process in a shared environment, you must send the environment id as a query parameter.

/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=salesgroup

But the flow functions do not have an input for the environment, so they automatically try to trigger a process in the public (default) environment.

By the way, the identifier for an environment can be found when you open the environment in the Control Tower.

The Workaround

The good news is SAP Build Apps recently added a new flow function called HTTP Destination Request that lets us create a customized HTTP request but using a destination. That is we get the control we get from the HTTP Request flow function but with the ability to connect through a destination.

As a prerequisite you need to have a destination called sap_process_automation_service_user_access to the SAP Build Process Automation service, the same as if you wanted to use the Processes flow functions. This is described in the Processes documentation.

You will need to add the destination properties so that it appears in your SAP Build Apps project:

BuildApps.Enabled = true
BuildApps.ApiType = rest

To add the destination to your project:

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.                                                         
  3.  Click BTP Destinations.
  4. Select the destination.
  5. Click Install Integration.                      

If you go back to the Integrations tab main screen, you'll see the destination. That's all you need to do to add the destination to the project and make it available to your HTTP Destination Request flow function.

To trigger a process deployed to a shared environment, do the following:

  1. Add a button.
  2. In the logic canvas for the button, add an HTTP Destination Request, along with any Alert flow functions to show the result or error
  3. Select the HTTP Destination Request, and set the following in the Properties tab.
    Destinationsap_process_automation_service_user_access
    HTTP MethodPOST
    Request Body Typejson
    Request BodyThis depends on the proper request body for your process. More on this below.
    Path
    /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=<environment ID>

    Replace the placeholder with the identifier for your environment.

    Response Typetext

       

The flow function has 3 outputs.

  • The first if the call is successful and returns 2XX status code.
  • The second if the call is successfully transmitted and a response is received but returns a 4XX or 5XX status code.
  • The third if the call is unsuccessful and no response is received.  

Request Body

The request body is determined by checking the trigger for the process.

  1. Go to the Control Tower.
  2. Click Environments.
  3. Click your environment.
  4. Click Triggers.
  5. Click View next to the trigger for your process.

You will now see the payload for the API for that trigger. This will be the request body.

Note that you cannot copy from the box with the payload. You will have to use the copy button to copy the entire payload. Note also you can see the URL for the API, including the environmentId parameter you must pass.

The Upshot

The method above is pretty straight-forward and has the advantage of teaching you what is happening behind the scenes and how the SAP Build Process Automation APIs work. But I'll admit you lose the ease of use of the flow functions, and also the ability to create variables from the input and output schema of your processes.

entry.title: SAP BTP - An Executive Introduction
entry.content:
@timoelliott is an innovation evangelist with SAP.  In this executive overview of SAP Business Technology Platform, Timo introduces the value of SAP BTP, its solutions, differentiators, key customer references and where to learn more. You can watch the original video here .

You may have noticed there's a lot of chaos in the modern world. Change seems to be changing faster, from pandemics that turn the world upside down to big, unexpected tariff changes that disrupt the world's supply chains overnight. And since everything relies on technology these days, reacting quickly to market changes means changing your computer systems. And that's not always as easy as it should be.

I'm sure you've seen this quote before: "Since the dawn of time, the key to survival has always been the ability to change." And yet, more than 80% of companies responding to a recent survey from McKinsey said they did not feel well-prepared to deal with rising volatility.

What are organizations looking to achieve? Well, in order to deal with faster change, we need to transform transformation — accelerate our ability to innovate. In conversations with you, our customers, we find three key themes. First, companies are looking to better connect and coordinate their teams across internal silos so the company can act as one. Second, they're looking to take advantage of AI and automation to be able to adjust back-end systems faster than is possible when everything is done manually. Third, everyone wants to explore new business models: selling connected services rather than just products, or moving to subscription pricing, or developing more customized services, and so on.

So while it's difficult to create a formal ROI case for business agility, the reality is it makes the difference between surviving and thriving. The ability to change faster than the competition is one of THE biggest and most powerful differentiators you can have in your industry.

But you don't need me to tell you that change is hard. You probably have lots of disparate, disconnected systems that have grown up over the years, and they all talk different languages. Maintenance probably takes up a big chunk of your time and resources. Making changes means wading into custom code and integrations and involves a lot of costs and above all, risk. These are, after all, the systems that keep your business running. And it can be difficult finding the people with the right skills to solve today's technology challenges. And the data backs this up.

70% of CIOs say their current systems lack the agility to scale and integrate with modern technologies like AI. 80% of CIOs cite data quality and semantic challenges as their biggest obstacles to AI success. And 45% of businesses operating on legacy systems are less likely to adopt enterprise-wide AI due to technology limitations.

We all know that business transformation isn't about technology, but it certainly relies heavily on it. So the CIO has a critical role helping shepherd the competing demands from different areas of the business while maintaining a coherent technology strategy and governance. At SAP, our Business Suite vision aims to enable CIOs as transformational chief innovation officers rather than just chief infrastructure officers. Where IT is a strategic partner for the organization, and goes beyond IT management to drive transformation: aligning technology with the business goals.

SAP Business Technology Platform is what we use as the foundation for SAP's own innovations, and we have over 150 different applications running on the platform. But of course, we also make it available to you and our vast ecosystem of partners to help all areas of the business succeed, in partnership with the CIO. The platform is most often used by IT departments, but it's all about creating better business outcomes.

So what is SAP BTP? Well, it's a multi-cloud platform-as-a-service to unlock the full potential of your business. Optimized to work with SAP solutions, it's a unified platform of best of breed technologies to extend and integrate business applications and to infuse artificial intelligence and context-aware business data into everything you do.

We know that there are lots of different development environments out there, so when and why might SAP BTP be the right solution for your business needs? First, we've been in the business of business processes for decades. SAP BTP has out-of-the-box support to connect your processes and applications to just about any other system and application on the planet. Second, it's built for business. When you're designing something to extend your existing business applications and processes, there's no point reinventing the wheel. You can just quickly and easily leverage all the user object to security information that's already in your system. Third, we've been building AI into our applications for years, and while it's easy to do quick and powerful proof of concept projects with the latest gen AI technology, all the analyst research research shows that the vast majority of AI projects fail to go into production or add business value. We have deep expertise in helping our customers build mission-critical systems. We built robust assembly lines to integrate relevant, reliable and responsible business AI into all of our applications and we provide the same tested, production-ready tools to you. And finally, studies have proved that BTP adds value to other SAP Business Suite applications with a strong return on investment when BTP is deployed together with applications like SAP Cloud ERP, Successfactors, Ariba, and Finance.

SAP BTP is available globally with 42 data centers worldwide. It's helped over 33,000 customers achieve measurable impact across all industries and lines of business. Over 10,000 pre-built best practice artifacts speed up your time to value with pre-implemented workflows, and with a growing ecosystem of 3,200 partners that have built industry and line of business solutions on top of the platform, you're likely to find out-of-the-box solutions for your particular needs. And SAP BTP is recognized by leading analyst firms as a best in class vendor, leading in numerous technology categories.

Let's dive into the real content. SAP BTP covers five major solution areas: integration, application development and automation, artificial intelligence, data and analytics, and platform foundation. Let's look at each of these key areas in a bit more detail.

 

First, integration. Integration is one of the most time consuming and painful parts of any innovation project today. Organizations typically juggle multiple integration solutions, creating complexity, which in turn leads to longer projects and disjointed systems that continue to jeopardize business resiliency. So how does Integration Suite help with these challenges? SAP Integration Suite is a modern, scalable, and secure integration platform-as-a-service, empowering businesses to integrate all applications, systems and data across all landscapes, with one solution offering comprehensive capabilities to accelerate productivity and ensure reliable connectivity. Thousands of pre-built content allow you to deploy faster and more easily, greatly increasing your time to value. There are over 3,900 built-in integrations, over 4,000 ready-to-use integration APIs for faster connectivity, and Gartner recently rated SAP Integration Suite a market leader for the fifth consecutive year running.

Harrods, the iconic luxury department store first opened its doors in Knightsbridge, London, in 1849. To support its digital transformation and strategic shift to a modern e-commerce platform, the company selected SAP Integration Suite to connect both cloud and on-premise technologies, internal and third-party systems across multiple protocols, all within a single platform. The result was a 40% reduction in total costs and 30% shorter process times, and with the standardization, Harrods can now more easily engage with partners and expand its global presence to meet increased customer demand in new markets, including China and the Middle East.

 

The second solution area for BTP is application development and automation. Building and extending enterprise applications with the wrong tools can be difficult and expensive, and deep collaboration between the business is always required for a successful outcome. Extensions need to be securely integrated with your core business systems. This is where SAP Build comes in. It provides tools for all levels of expertise, from professional developers to power users who only want to drag and drop to create applications. Analyst studies show that SAP Build drives 3X developer productivity and you can start coding with natural language: AI now understands your business, technology, data, and context. Deep integration with SAP and non-SAP applications provides the fastest way to create an application, automated process, or business site in a clean-core way. There are already over 17,000 customers using SAP Build solutions.

For example, in order to engage with the Gen Z audience, engineering multinational ThyssenKrupp has launched a new social media recruiting channel. The core of this approach is an app built in-house using the low-code SAP Build Apps development environment, helping citizen developers create and manage workflows for different HR applications. The intuitive app empowers personnel in more than 100 different HR departments to quickly create application flows for different job types, without needing any coding skills. This helps ThyssenKrupp respond to changing recruitment requirements in an agile and efficient way.

 

The third solution area of BTP we’ll look at is artificial intelligence. We could obviously talk for hours about AI, but the key challenges are that there are not enough resources to adopt AI as quickly as everybody would like across the enterprise, that the business data required for scaling AI is typically very fragmented, and that large language models are not always accurate and trustworthy. The AI in BTP is designed for trust. We have built a production-ready AI orchestration platform to allow you to embed AI into all of your business processes with confidence. We use that platform to provide over 230 individual use cases across the SAP Business Suite, and we're training specific AI models on high-quality, industry-specific tabular business data, and leveraging our deep process knowledge. In addition, AI is built into all of the BTP solutions such as Joule studio and Build for developers.

 

For example, when Germany was hit by a sharp rise in energy prices recently because of getting cut off from Russian gas, the City of Hamburg used SAP AI services and other solutions to efficiently process almost 100,000 applications relating to aid. The financial aid platform was launched in only two weeks, and allowed the city of Hamburg to start distributing €2.5 billion in special fund to public and private cultural institutions. It's an intuitive, self-service platform that leverages generative AI to support a digitalized application process for cultural events, including the initial request, the validity checks, objection handling and payment. BTP and AI greatly sped up the processing of the applications far quicker than would otherwise been possible.

 

The fourth solution area of BTP is data and analytics provided by Business Data Cloud. Business users need data for all of their analytics planning needs in real time, with full business context. At SAP, we believe this requires integration between all data platforms and business applications with data products based on a one-domain model for consistency—and connecting insights and business decisions is now more important than ever in the new AI era. SAP Business Data Cloud accelerates the process of turning data into decisions with “insights-as-a-service”: pre-built, out-of-the-box analytic apps to help you make smart decisions faster. They leverage fully-managed, curated data products across all lines of business, providing advanced analytics and planning apps across core enterprise, analytics, finance, people, and much more. It unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third party data using Delta Sharing and Data Federation to connect all your data with zero copies. And you can easily create AI apps and AI models trained on your business data, using for example, SAP Databricks.
